title: Wayne Shaw dominates the headlines but the circus he's helped create belittles non-league football
text:

There was an issue with it even before the Gambling Commission tapped on Sutton's door. 
With that ill-advised pasty-eating stunt, Wayne Shaw - the roly-poly-goalie - believed he was simply enjoying a bit of fun from which his mates could cash in. 
Trouble is, THAT picture of the 45-year-old tucking in became the defining image of Sutton’s heroics. 
Those wins over Cheltenham, AFC Wimbledon and Leeds - ahead of that valiant defeat to Arsenal - have been a footnote as Shaw, who didn’t even play on Monday night, continues to dominate the headlines. 
Pick up a paper, turn on Breakfast TV or scroll through social media. Few people are talking about Roarie Deacon’s 25-yard effort against the bar or Adam May’s chance from David Ospina’s poor clearance. Wayne Shaw on the Sutton bench (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Wayne Shaw petition launched to have goalkeeper reinstated 
Shaw's late snack has perpetuated the incorrect notion that non-league players are happy to enjoy “a bit of fun” instead of putting in the hard yards as they aspire to bigger things. 
Shaw himself has worked as hard as anybody to get Sutton to where they are today. He has been groundsman as well as goalkeeper and has put in years of service at the club. 
But this circus plays right into the hands of people who want to keep non-league football in its box. People who’d rather not accept that players are fitter and far more focused at that level, as a relieved Arsene Wenger found on Monday night. 
Many of us have been used over the years to writing about non-league players who doubled up as butchers, bakers and candlestick makers. It is an old tale, often (tediously) told. What did his teammates make of things? (Photo: REUTERS) What about the likes of Craig Eastmond's efforts though? (Photo: David Price) What of Paul Doswell's efforts? (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Read More 
The Sutton team, however, included a number of former Arsenal players eager to make their way back up the leagues. 
Men like Craig Eastmond, who played for the Gunners in the Premier League and the Champions League. 
So why is it that football is seen to have lost its humour regarding an incident for which a Premier League star would probably be hammered? 
As for the betting, the point has already been made. Shaw broke the FA rules. He admits being aware of the odds and that a few of his mates were on at 8-1. Wayne Shaw on 'Good Morning Britain' (Photo: Rex Features) 
He explained: “A few of the lads said to me earlier on: ‘What is going on with the 8-1 about eating a pie?’ I said: ‘I don’t know, I’ve eaten nothing all day, so I might give it a go later on,’” he said. 
“Sun Bets had us at 8-1 to eat a pie. I thought I would give them a bit of banter and let’s do it. All the subs were on and we were 2-0 down. 
“I went and got it at half time from the kitchen, I had it all prepared and ready to go. It was meat and potato.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
